narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned so much in this course. Firstly, I was sort of scared to take a writing course but this course is welcoming to people of all writing skills. You really get to learn how to close read readings and analyze movies and photos. My writing because so well structured and I think my thought process for writing has improved a lot. You're really given a great introduction to college writing which is applicable to all classes that succeed this one.

I learned how to read critically as well as hone in my writing skills. I had no experience analyzing paintings or art and this class allowed me to develop this skill set. Moreover, it improved my analytical writing ability, especially with the research paper.
I developed how to close-read pieces of art, and develop my own original arguments in doing so. I also learned how to conduct research and write a research paper.
I worked on my critical thinking and close reading skills.
Close-reading, interpreting images including paintings, writing college-level essay

Sarah helped me find my voice this semester. We analyzed many interesting cultural piecesfrom classic literature to modern artwork and even science fiction moviesand learned how methods of "close-reading" transcend written work. The long research paper was also a tremendous learning experience. Sarah walked us through all phases of the writing and revising processes, and I feel more comfortable now approaching any future paper.
This course provided students the opportunity to look at ambiguous figures, drawings, places, or writings and conceptualize, as well as discuss, subtle ideas their creators intended to portray.

I learned to write research papers, engage with readings and, more generally, write better. Aside from that, there was also a session where a librarian came in to explain about the steps of research (what to look for, how to find sources). This was an incredibly helpful class to take in my first semester at Yale.
How to write a literary research paper, how to write a critical essay. Expository writing skills in general.
I learned how to write a college research paper and I was allowed to explore a more creative form of an argumentative paper.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There are no weaknesses. This course was completely amazing and I loved it so much. All the readings were so interesting and the environment that Sarah created in class made me feel super comfortable with sharing my ideas during discussion. She was always willing to meet with students to discuss papers, readings, or anything. Even though class time was long, it never felt long. I really felt like I was learning and I was never stressed about assignments in this course.
My instructor did an amazing job teaching the course and I felt like the class was well organized.

Strengths include an amazing professor who keeps the class engaging while listening to the students and adjusting workload accordingly. It was also fascinating reading material, that lent itself to discussion. The timeline of ENGL114 is slightly demanding as a freshman, which was good in that it pushed us, however providing more leniency could improve the course.

Strength - very interesting choices of topic, enjoyable readings and projects
Weaknesses - None

Sarah does a great job of involving her students. She makes sure to include discussion contributions from everyone. The only weakness I found of this course reflects more on the subject than on the instructor: English is far better in person!

the course overall was full of strengths and very little weaknesses. From fun topics and a passionate teacher, to active classmates and friendly environment for learning, this class truly had all aspects one could ask for in an english section.

Strengths: interesting theme (besides ghosts, spies and shadows, we were also looking at the "act of disappearance" so everyone had something to contribute), flexibility (Sarah really wants you to write about something you're interested in, so she gives a lot of room in deciding your specific topic for the papers), professor (she really cares about each of her students). The readings selected were also interesting and feedback for each paper was helpful in finding areas of improvement. 
There were no weaknesses in particular.

Strengths: excellent professor
Weaknessess: virtual lectures made engaging discussions difficult

Strengths: I was very engaged because it was such a small class and we all received a lot of attention from the professor.
Weaknesses: the class took place at a very late hour

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think live seminar actually worked really well. The only downside was I wasn't able to get to know my classmates as well, but that's a bit difficult to overcome during the pandemic. Zoom allowed us to freely share screen to show what we wanted to everyone. I think overall everything worked pretty well.
Small class sizes really help with this type of learning so I felt adequately supported.
I believe this seminar worked well through zoom, maybe advising to keep mics on could improve engagement. Our coordinated movie viewing was also effective in giving it a genuine "class feel."
The course was flexible to our needs.
I think keeping the Live Zoom sessions and making it kind of mandatory (no recorded lectures posted) made it more engaging

Strengths: making sure everyone's voices were heard, interspersing videos and other engaging content to maintain our attention, relying on polls and the zoom chat. Weaknesses: lecturing, long presentation, etc.

There were many different course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. We mostly had discussions in class, so the Zoom format worked fine. We also had a movie screening in class where the professor shared her screen and audio. With student presentations, we shared each of our screens/slides/videos and presented. While we couldnt visit the Beinecke or the YUAG in person, we visited the collections online and picked artworks related to the course theme to present in class. All these methods were effective in encouraging virtual engagement.
Virtual lectures were adequate, but no substitute for in-class discussions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. I would absolutely 100% sure recommend this course to another student. This was definitely the best course I've taken at Yale thus far. I was never even interested in anything else besides STEM but this course was so eye opening and made me really fall in love with writing. Even if the readings are a bit long at times, they are all so so interesting which made them fun to read. The movies we got to watch were also really great to, and analyzing them was really enjoyable.
Yes, this class is a good intro writing course and helps you understand what is expected in a college writing class.

Absolutely with Sarah as the professor - very supportive and accommodating, and gives productive feedback. The course itself is very interesting, and teaches important analyzing and writing skills, especially for a freshman.
Yes!!! Take this course, especially with Sarah! I grew so much as a writer and learned a ton!
Yes! Professor Weston is probably the best professor at Yale I have ever had. The topic is engaging and educational.

I would highly recommend this course! Sarah does an amazing job bringing English 114 to life. This particular section of "Ghosts, Spies, Shadows" is particularly interesting, as in my opinion it covers the most pertinent subject matter with the most interesting array of primary and secondary sources.
Very strongly recommend to any students.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. The course itself is a great introduction to college writing, but what makes it better is Sarah. She is incredible. Throughout the course, she was passionate about what she was teaching, and I could tell she cared about each student. After each paper, she gave lengthy and helpful feedback on how I could improve my writing. She also led each discussion well, so everyone was comfortable speaking up (the small course size probably contributed to this as well). This was easily my favorite course for the fall semester, and I am so glad I took it.
Yes, if you are looking to enhance your writing skills and earn a WR credit along the way.
I would! Professor Weston was an excellent teacher and I learned so much from her this semester in terms of reading, writing, thinking, and speaking. The course topic was also very interesting.
